questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlorine compound

 

Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

 

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenolic compound: Phenolic compounds are effective disinfectants but are generally less effective against a broad spectrum of bloodborne pathogens compared to chlorine compounds.

 

Option C. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Quaternary ammonium compounds are good for general disinfection but are not recommended for blood spills as they are less effective against non-enveloped viruses and spores.

 

Option D. Alcoholic compounds: Alcohol-based disinfectants are effective for surface disinfection but are not ideal for blood spills as they can coagulate proteins, making blood more difficult to clean.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cleaning a blood spill in the operation theatre, sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant due to its effectiveness in inactivating a wide range of pathogens and its suitability for such critical environments.

choices.text: No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

questions.text: A resident had a needle stick injury while dealing with a Hepatitis B positive patient. Serology was done and HBsAg was negative and the Anti-HBs was >105 mIU/ml. What is the next step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

 

No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination: The resident's serology shows that HBsAg is negative and Anti-HBs is greater than 105 mIU/ml, which indicates that he has sufficient immunity against Hepatitis B from prior vaccination. No further treatment is necessary because the antibody titres are already protective.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Booster dose of vaccine: Not required since the resident already has sufficient antibody levels indicating immunity.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin with full vaccination: This would be necessary if the resident had low or no detectable antibody titres, indicating no prior immunity.

 

Option C. Repeat full course of vaccine: Not necessary because the resident already has adequate antibody titres indicating immunity.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Which of the following test is used for antibiotic sensitivity? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E-test (Epsilometer test)

 

The E-test or Epsilometer test is specifically designed for antibiotic sensitivity testing. It involves:

 

  • Using a Muller-Hinton agar (MHA) plate as the culture medium
  • Streaking the test organism on the plate
  • Applying an E-strip containing gradients of antibiotic concentrations
  • The strip has increasing antibiotic concentration going up and decreasing concentration going down
  • Where the zone of inhibition intersects the strip indicates the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of the antibiotic
  • Formation of an elliptical zone of inhibition around the strip indicates susceptibility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elek's test

 

  • This is used for detecting diphtheria toxin production by Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • It's a gel precipitation test where antitoxin strips are used to detect toxin production
  • Not related to antibiotic sensitivity testing

 

Option C. Latex agglutination test

 

  • This is an agglutination-based test used for various diagnostic purposes
  • Used for detecting antigens or antibodies in clinical specimens
  • Not used for determining antibiotic sensitivity

 

Option D. CAMP test

 

  • Used to detect beta-hemolysis
  • Primarily used for identifying Group B Streptococcus (S. agalactiae) and Listeria
  • Not related to antibiotic susceptibility testing

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E-test (Epsilometer test) is the standard method for determining the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of antibiotics against bacteria using an antibiotic gradient strip.

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical mupirocin

 

Topical mupirocin is the preferred agent for the elimination of nasal carriers of MRSA.

 

Decolonization therapy is the administration of antimicrobial or antiseptic agents to eradicate or suppress MRSA carriage:

 

  • Intranasal antibiotic or antiseptic (e.g., mupirocin, povidone-iodine)
  • Topical antiseptic (e.g., chlorhexidine)
  • +/- Systemic antibiotics

 

MRSA decolonization has been associated with reduction in MRSA carriage, transmission and infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral vancomycin: While effective against MRSA, oral vancomycin is not used for nasal decolonization. It is primarily used for treating severe systemic MRSA infections and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea.

 

Option B. Inj cephalosporin: Cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics that are generally ineffective against MRSA due to resistance mechanisms. They are not used for MRSA nasal decolonization.

 

Option D. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is an antibiotic used for treating multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections, particularly in the lungs. It is not used for nasal decolonization of MRSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical mupirocin is the recommended treatment for the nasal decolonization of MRSA, effectively reducing the nasal carriage of the bacteria and thereby decreasing the risk of transmission and subsequent infections.

questions.text: A patient from a military background presented with rash, fever, and altered sensorium. There is also a deficiency of the membrane attacking complex. The likely cause can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that commonly causes meningococcal infections, which can lead to serious conditions such as meningococcemia and meningitis. Patients with a deficiency in the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system, specifically components C5 to C9, are at an increased risk of Neisserial infections. The MAC plays a crucial role in defending against Neisseria species by forming pores in the bacterial cell membrane, leading to cell lysis. Without this complex, individuals are susceptible to recurrent or disseminated Neisserial infections, which manifest with symptoms like rash, fever, and altered sensorium, as seen in this patient. The clinical presentation of rash, fever, and altered sensorium strongly suggests meningococcemia, a severe form of infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause a variety of symptoms, primarily in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with rash, fever, and altered sensorium linked to MAC deficiency.

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and other infections, particularly in hospital settings. It does not have a direct correlation with MAC deficiency and does not typically present with disseminated infections characterized by rash, fever, and altered sensorium.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae: While Hemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections and meningitis, it is not specifically associated with MAC deficiency and does not fit the profile of disseminated Neisserial infections seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) of the complement system are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can lead to severe conditions like meningococcemia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the causative agent associated with in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pure red cell aplasia

 

  • The provided picture displays the typical appearance of a slapped cheek  due to cutaneous vasodilatation, indicating a probable case of erythema infectiosum.
  • This condition is caused by the Parvovirus B19.
  • Parvovirus B19 is linked to pure red cell aplasia.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingivostomatitisis can be caused by Herpes virus.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum is an infection caused by a poxvirus 

 

Option D. Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19, the causative agent of erythema infectiosum, is associated with pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schencki

 

The above lesion is most likely caused by  Sporothrix schencki (S. schenckii)

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardener's Disease," is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the saprophytic dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus. In its saprophytic stage or when cultured at 25°C, it assumes a filamentous form, composed of hyaline, septate hyphae 1 to 2 μm wide, with conidiogenous cells arising from undifferentiated hyphae forming conidia in groups on small, clustered denticles. These one-celled conidia are tear shaped to clavate and do not yield chains. The S. schenckii colonies never become cottony or floccose.

Infection with the dimorphic soil fungus S schenckii is usually transmitted by the mold form from organic matter through cutaneous inoculation. The mycosis has also been transmitted from animals through bites or scratches.

 

The initial reddish, necrotic, nodular papule of cutaneous sporotrichosis generally appears 1-10 weeks after a penetrating skin injury. The lesion is a suppurating granuloma that consists of histiocytes and giant cells, with neutrophils that accumulate in the center and that are surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells.

 

The fungal infection spreads from the initial lesion along lymphatic channels, forming the chain of indolent nodular and ulcerating lesions typical of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other tissues are involved by direct extension and, less often, by hematogenous dissemination. The most common extracutaneous infection sites are in the bones, joints, tendon sheaths, and bursae. Hematogenous dissemination—particularly in immunocompromised hosts—results in widely disseminated cutaneous and visceral infection, including meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen. It may cause pulmonary disease and local lymphadenitis, primarily in the submandibular and submaxillary regions. It is usually a benign, self-limited condition with no systemic symptoms except for mild neck pain.

 

Option C. Eumyectoma or mycetoma also called as Madura foot, is a chronic subcutaneous granulomatous soft-tissue infection. The etiological agent may be fungal (eumycetoma) or bacterial (actinomycetoma) and appears under microscopic examination as hyphae or thin filaments, respectively. The cardinal features of the disease are tumefaction, sinus formation, and presentation of grains or granules in draining exudate.

 

Option D. Phialophora verrucosa is a common cause of chromoblastomycosis. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. The fungus is seen as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, (known as sclerotic bodies) on histology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii, the cause of sporotrichosis, typically presents as a chain of nodular and ulcerating lesions along lymphatic channels following traumatic inoculation, earning it the name "Rose Gardener's Disease."

choices.text: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins
5-12 years is a high-risk group

questions.text: Which of the following is false about influenza? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5-12 years is a high-risk group

 

People at greater risk of severe disease or complications when infected are:

 

  1. pregnant women
  2. Children under 59 months
  3. Elderly
  4. Individuals with chronic medical conditions (such as chronic cardiac, pulmonary, renal, metabolic, neurodevelopmental, liver or hematologic diseases)
  5. Individuals with immunosuppressive conditions (such as HIV/AIDS, receiving chemotherapy or steroids, or malignancy).
  6. Health care workers are at high risk acquiring influenza virus infection due to increased exposure to the patients and risk further spread particularly to vulnerable individuals.

 

Mode of transmission – droplet infection

 

Incubation period – 1 to 4 days

 

Contagious period - About one day before developing any symptoms and up to seven days after the symptoms resolve.

 

Birds, especially aquatic birds act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza or bird flu refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR), defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (i.e., household or close contacts), can provide an indication of how social interactions relate to transmission risk. It is 5- 15% for influenza.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Virus shedding is present before symptoms begin: This is true. Influenza can be contagious before symptoms appear, which contributes to its rapid spread.

 

Option C. Aquatic birds act as a reservoir: This is true. Birds, especially aquatic birds, act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza, or bird flu, refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

Option D. Secondary attack rate is 5-15%: This is true. The secondary attack rate (SAR) for influenza, defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (e.g., household or close contacts), is typically between 5-15%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children under 5 years, pregnant women, the elderly, individuals with chronic medical conditions or immunosuppressive conditions, and health care workers are at greater risk of severe disease or complications from influenza. The 5-12 years age group is not specifically categorized as high-risk for severe disease from influenza.

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 m) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoisospora

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

 

Points in favor:

 

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: Cyclospora oocysts are smaller (8-12 µm) and round, with variable acid-fast staining. They sporulate in soil and contain two sporocysts with two sporozoites each.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are even smaller (4-6 µm) and round. They are uniformly acid-fast and contain four sporozoites. Sporulation occurs inside the host cell.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are obligate intracellular parasites that do not have the same oocyst structure as coccidian parasites. They are detected by different staining methods and appear as small spores rather than larger oocysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

questions.text: A confirmed case of which of the following viral hemorrhagic fevers was found in India? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Nairovirus species. This disease is zoonotic, meaning it originates from animals, with ticks acting as vectors.

 

Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF):

 

  • Causative Agent: Nairovirus species.
  • Transmission: The primary vectors are ticks, specifically those of the Hyalomma genus.
  • Outbreaks: The disease can spread through person-to-person transmission, particularly in healthcare settings, where it poses a significant risk to healthcare workers and patients.
  • Symptoms: Include fever, muscle pain, dizziness, neck pain and stiffness, backache, headache, sore eyes, and photophobia. Severe cases can lead to extensive hemorrhaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebola: Ebola is another severe viral hemorrhagic fever but has not been reported in India. It primarily affects regions in Africa.

 

Option B. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is a mosquito-borne viral hemorrhagic disease endemic to Africa and South America. It has not been reported in India.

 

Option D. Marburg: Marburg virus causes a severe hemorrhagic fever similar to Ebola. It has also not been reported in India and is primarily found in Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is the viral hemorrhagic fever that has been confirmed in India. It is caused by the Nairovirus species and is transmitted by ticks, with potential for person-to-person transmission, especially in healthcare settings.

questions.text: What type of budding is described by a broad base with a small bud coming off of it, often associated with a figure of 8 appearances? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastomycosis

 

The term "broad based budding" refers to a type of asexual reproduction in fungi where the bud forms from a broad base rather than a narrow one. This specific budding pattern is characteristic of Blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. The appearance of the yeast cells in Blastomycosis is often described as having a broad base with a budding structure that resembles a figure of 8. This visual characteristic is useful in distinguishing Blastomycosis from other fungal infections. The mnemonic "Blasto" helps to remember that "Blasto" implies broad-based budding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: This fungus is known for producing yeast cells with a round, encapsulated appearance and does not exhibit broad-based budding. Instead, it forms a distinctive capsule around the yeast cells which is crucial for its identification.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: The causative agent, Candida species, typically shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms, but these do not have the broad-based budding pattern. Candida's budding is more narrow-based compared to that of Blastomycosis.

 

Option D.Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, this fungus forms small yeast cells within macrophages. The budding in Histoplasmosis is more narrow-based and does not resemble the broad-based budding pattern described for Blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomycosis is characterized by broad-based budding with a figure of 8 appearances, where the term "Blasto" helps recall the broad base nature of the budding structure.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

choices.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days
Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

 

A Giemsa-stained peripheral blood smear shows many red blood cells (RBCs) infected with classic, ring-shaped and headphone-shaped trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum parasite. High degree of parasitemia and RBCs infected with two or more trophozoites were seen, a finding typical of P. falciparum malaria.

 

Cerebral malaria is a complicated form of malaria associated with multisystem organ dysfunction and high degree of morbidity and mortality. These patients often present with impaired consciousness, delirium and convulsions. It is a medical emergency where prompt diagnosis and early institution of treatment can be lifesaving. Intravenous quinine or artesunate are the mainstays of treatment in cerebral malaria.

 

Management of Cerebral Malaria:

 

  • Artesunate: Administered intravenously at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg immediately, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then once daily if necessary.
  • Alternative Treatment:
    • Artemether: 3.2 mg/kg intramuscularly initially, followed by 1.6 mg/kg once daily.
    • Quinine dihydrochloride: 20 mg of salt/kg infused over 4 hours, followed by 10 mg of salt/kg infused over 2-8 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline 100 mg intravenously for 7 days: Doxycycline is not the first-line treatment for severe malaria. It is typically used as a secondary prophylactic measure or in combination with other antimalarial drugs.

 

Option B. Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days: Clindamycin is not used for the treatment of malaria. It is an antibiotic that is used for bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Chloroquine intramuscularly 8 hourly for 3 days: Chloroquine is ineffective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance. It is also not suitable for treating severe or cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. A stool examination was done, and it showed the presence of the organism shown in image A. The body has segments broader than the length. Which of the eggs shown in column B corresponds to this organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given image shows characteristic features of Hymenolepis nana. This can be identified by its body segments being broader than long.

 

The egg of hymenolepis nana is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore with 6 hooklets as seen in the image. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

 

The most likely organism based on the given history and image is Trichophyton rubrum. The colonies appear velvety and a deep red, non-diffusible pigment is seen when viewed from the reverse side of the colony. A few long and pencil-shaped macroconidia can be seen.

 

Trichophyton is a dermatophytic fungi that can infect hair, skin, or nails. Dermatophytes infect only the keratinized tissue and have keratinases that can digest keratin. There are 3 genera of dermatophytes:

 

  • ﻿﻿Trichophyton - The colonies may appear powdery, waxy, or velvety with pigmentation characteristics of different species.
  • ﻿﻿Epidermophyton - It infects the skin and nails, but not the hair. The colonies appear powdery and greenish-yellow.
  • Microsporum - It infects the hair and skin, but not the nails. The colonies may appear cotton-like, velvety, or powdery, with white to brown pigmentation.

 

Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea corporis. It results from the invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum, with lesions on the trunk and limbs. The lesions are usually well-defined and circular with a raised edge. It can also cause tinea pedis, tinea cruris, and onychomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The colonies of Trichophyton violaceus are very slow-growing, waxy with a violet/purple pigment. They have distorted hyphae, with conidia seen rarely.

 

 

Option C. Trichophyton tonsurans has a cream or yellowish colony with central furrows. Microconidia are abundantly seen. Thick-walled, irregular macroconidia are also seen.

 

 

Option D. Colonies of Trichophyton schoenleinii are smooth, waxy and brownish. Hyphal swellings are seen along with chlamydospores and favic chandelier.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is a dematiaceous fungus? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cladosporium

 

  • The dematiaceous (brown-pigment) fungi are a large and heterogenous group of molds that cause a wide range of diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.
  • Among the more important human pathogens are Alternaria species, Bipolaris species, Cladophialophora (Cladosporium) bantiana, Curvularia species, Exophiala species, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Madurella species, Phialophora species, Scedosporium prolificans, Scytalidium dimidiatum, and Wangiella dermatitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor species: Incorrect Mucor species are not dematiaceous fungi. They are non-pigmented (hyaline) fungi that cause mucormycosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
 

Option B. Aspergillus niger: Incorrect Aspergillus niger is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a black mold, but it does not belong to the group of dematiaceous fungi. It is a common cause of aspergillosis.
 

Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Incorrect Blastomyces dermatitidis is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a dimorphic fungus that causes blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cladosporium is a dematiaceous fungus, characterized by its dark pigmentation due to melanin in its cell walls, and it is associated with various diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

 

Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

 

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

 

Functions of pili:

 

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic membrane: While important for many cellular functions, the cytoplasmic membrane itself is not typically involved in adhesion.

 

Option B. Mesosomes: These are folded invaginations in the bacterial membrane thought to be artifacts of cell preparation and not involved in adhesion.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharides (LPS): Found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, LPS can play a role in interactions with the host immune system but are not primarily responsible for adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: The test shown in the image below. Which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.

 

Among the options given, Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is catalase-positive and does not typically exhibit bacitracin sensitivity. It is identified by coagulase testing and its ability to grow in the presence of high salt concentrations.

 

Option C. Clostridium botulinum: Clostridium botulinum is an anaerobic Gram-positive rod and is not identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Option D. Bacillus: Bacillus species are Gram-positive rods that form spores and are not typically identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Educational Objective

 

The bacitracin disk test is used to identify Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by its sensitivity to bacitracin and beta-hemolytic activity on blood agar. This test differentiates S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, which are resistant to bacitracin.

choices.text: They are unable to mount inflammation against the virus
Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA
There is a risk of elevation of transaminases
Liver parenchymal cells are in a state of high proliferation

questions.text: There are 3 to 5% healthy hepatitis B carriers in India who are asymptomatic. They are at the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma in the future because? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA

 

In most tumors, HBV DNA is integrated into the cell genome, and in most cases, the virus DNA has undergone rearrangements, including deletions. After integration, it promotes the overexpression of cell genes that can also contribute to oncogenesis.

 

The only viral gene product that is consistently present in the tumor cells is the X protein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Inability to mount inflammation against the virus is not the primary reason for the increased risk of HCC.

 

Option C: Elevated transaminases indicate liver inflammation but are not directly related to the integration of viral DNA and oncogenesis.

 

Option D: High proliferation of liver parenchymal cells is not the primary reason for the increased risk of HCC due to HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus can integrate its DNA into the host genome, leading to genetic mutations and increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Match the following eggs to the organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. The Hymenolepis nana egg - The egg is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryopore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere.  The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

2. Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm)

 

Two types of eggs are passed by the worms: (1) fertilized and (2) unfertilized.

 

  1. The fertilized eggs, laid by females, inseminated by mating with a male, are embryonated and develop into the infective eggs (Figs 3A to C. .
  2. The unfertilized eggs, are laid by uninseminated female. These are nonembryonated and cannot become infective

 

Features of roundworm egg

 

 

 

3. The egg of Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) is:

 

Oval or elliptical, measuring 60 μm by 40 mcm.

 

Colorless, not bile stained.

 

Surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.

 

Floats in saturated salt solution.

 

When released by the worm in the intestine, the egg contains an unsegmented ovum.

 

During its passage down the intestine, the ovum develops. When passed in feces, the egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with four or eight blastomeres.

 

There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and the egg shell (Figs A and B).

 

 

4. The eggs of Taenia solium and Tania saginata are indistinguishable.

 

The egg is spherical, measuring 30-40 mcm diameter. lt has a thin hyaline embryonic membrane around it, which soon disappears after release. The inner embryophore is radially striated and is yellow brown due to bile staining. In the center is a fully-developed embryo (oncosphere) with three pairs of hooklets (hexacanth embryo). The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to humans, whereas the eggs of T. solium are infective to pigs and humans too.

questions.text: Specimen handling for molecular testing of SARS CoV-2 would require? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BSL2

 

Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2) is required for handling specimens for molecular testing of SARS-CoV-2. BSL-2 facilities are designed for work involving agents that pose moderate hazards to personnel and the environment. This includes diagnostic and other procedures involving the manipulation of known or suspected infectious materials, such as SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19.

 

For culturing SARS-CoV-2, which involves growing the virus, higher containment is necessary. Therefore, BSL-3 facilities would be required to ensure higher levels of protection against aerosol transmission and potential infection.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. BSL1: This level is used for work with well-characterized agents that are not known to consistently cause disease in healthy adults and present minimal potential hazard to laboratory personnel and the environment. It is not suitable for handling SARS-CoV-2 specimens.

 

Option C. BSL3: While this level is appropriate for culturing SARS-CoV-2 due to the need for higher containment, it is not required for routine molecular testing.

 

Option D. BSL4: This level is reserved for work with dangerous and exotic agents that pose a high risk of aerosol-transmitted laboratory infections and life-threatening disease. It is not necessary for handling SARS-CoV-2 specimens for molecular testing.

 

Educational Objective

 

SARS CoV 2 requires BSL-2 or equivalent facilities.

choices.text: 1, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 4
2, 3 and 4

questions.text:
Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Glutaraldehyde
  2. Ethylene oxide
  3. Pasteurization
  4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Glutaraldehyde, Ethylene oxide, and Ortho-phthalaldehyde are effective methods of disinfection and sterilization that can kill spores.

 

1. Glutaraldehyde: This chemical is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It is known for its compatibility with a variety of medical instruments. However, it requires activation and produces irritant fumes, which are notable disadvantages. Despite these drawbacks, glutaraldehyde is commonly recommended for the disinfection of fibroscopes and respiratory equipment due to its efficacy against spores and other microorganisms.

 

2. ETO (Ethylene oxide) inactivates all microorganisms although bacterial spores (especially B. atrophaeus) are more resistant than other microorganisms. For this reason B. atrophaeus is the recommended biological indicator. ETO is used in healthcare facilities to sterilize critical items (and sometimes semicritical items) that are moisture or heat sensitive and cannot be sterilized by steam sterilization like syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves. Bacillus atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilis are used as sterilization control.

 

4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde: Similar to glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It does not require activation and does not produce irritating fumes, which are significant advantages. However, it is costly and can stain medical equipment. It is often used as an alternative to glutaraldehyde for disinfecting scopes.

 

Other Options

 

3. Pasteurization or pasteurization is a process of food preservation in which packaged and non-packaged foods (such as milk and fruit juices) are treated with mild heat, usually to less than 100 °C (212 °F), to eliminate pathogens and extend shelf life. It has no sporicidal activity and kills non-spore-forming bacteria like Mycobacteria, Brucella, and Salmonella. There are two methods-

 

  1. Holder method -  milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes. Coxiella burnetii is relatively heat resistant and may survive the holder method.
  2. Flash method - milk is heated at 72°C for 15-20 seconds followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Tzanck cells
Pund cells

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tzanck cells

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of genital herpes.

 

Tzanck cells – multinucleate giant cells seen on Tzanck smear in herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Herpetic lesions usually begin as clusters of small bumps, then blisters, followed by open sores or ulcers. Lesions coalesce and usually heal over several weeks at various rates. Local pain is a prominent and common complaint. Patients with genital herpes may also complain of pain in the groin area secondary to local adenopathy. Women often present with complaints of genital swelling, discharge, and dysuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pund cells: Donovan bodies are seen within large, mononuclear (Pund) cells as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies. Seen in granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) which is a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Donovanosis lesions usually start as a painless papule or subcutaneous nodule. The lesions develop the classic “beefy-red” appearance due to their high vascularity. The initial lesion takes on an ulcerative morphology after minor trauma. There is usually no regional lymphadenopathy. Developing subcutaneous granulomas known as pseudo buboes is possible.

 

 

Option C. Henderson-Patterson bodies: intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies, or Henderson-Paterson bodies) are seen in molluscum contagiosum. Lesions are painless, discrete, nontender, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules (bumps, dimples) that show a central umbilication.

 

 

Option D. Guarnieri bodies: B-type inclusions, formerly known as Guarnieri bodies are cellular features found upon microscopic inspection of epithelial cells of individuals suspected of having poxvirus or vaccinia virus.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of Tzanck cells, which are multinucleated giant cells, is indicative of herpes simplex virus infection. This is the most likely microscopic finding in a patient with painful genital lesions consistent with genital herpes.

choices.text: Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic
That the patient is in window period

questions.text: The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV2 in the blood likely indicates? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV 2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection even if the patient has been asymptomatic.

 

1-3 weeks after symptoms onset, SARS CoV2 antibody become detectable. At this time infectiousness is decreased and some amount of immunity from future infection has developed.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Presence of acute viral load: The presence of antibodies does not indicate an acute viral load. Acute infection is usually detected through the presence of viral RNA using PCR tests, not antibodies.

 

Option C. A high risk of reinfection: The presence of antibodies suggests that the individual has some level of immunity, which generally reduces the risk of reinfection rather than increasing it.

 

Option D. That the patient is in window period: The window period refers to the time after initial infection when antibodies are not yet detectable. Therefore, the presence of antibodies indicates that the patient is beyond the window period.

 

Educational objective

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection, which may have been asymptomatic. This serological evidence shows that the person has developed an immune response to the virus.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

 

Available HPV vaccines protect against either two, four, or nine types of HPV. All HPV vaccines protect against at least HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the greatest risk of cervical cancer. It is estimated that HPV vaccines may prevent 70% of cervical cancer, 80% of anal cancer, 60% of vaginal cancer, 40% of vulvar cancer, and show more than 90% efficacy in preventing HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers. They additionally prevent some genital warts, with the quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines that protect against HPV types HPV-6 and HPV-11 providing greater protection.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E6, E7: These proteins are oncogenes that contribute to the development of cancer by interfering with tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and Rb but are not components of the vaccine.

 

Option C. E1, E2: These are early proteins involved in the replication and regulation of HPV DNA but are not used in the vaccine formulation.

 

Option D. L2: This is a minor capsid protein of HPV, but the vaccine primarily uses the major capsid protein L1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HSV2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:


HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: GeneXpert detects mutations in which of the following genes? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) rроB

 

GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic tool widely used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin. It identifies mutations in the rpoB gene, which encodes the beta subunit of RNA polymerase. These mutations are responsible for rifampicin resistance, a critical marker for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

rpoB: The target gene for rifampicin resistance detection by GeneXpert. Mutations here confer rifampicin resistance

 

WHO strongly recommends Xpert assay for the diagnosis of TB and multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB in patients with HIV infection (WHO 2013).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. inhA: The inhA gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid and ethionamide. However, GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option C. katG: The katG gene is associated with resistance to isoniazid, another key TB drug. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Option D. pncA: The pncA gene is associated with resistance to pyrazinamide. GeneXpert does not detect mutations in this gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gene(s) involved in anti-tuberculosis drug resistance –

questions.text: Which virus requires reverse transcriptase PCR for detection? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RSV

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is an RNA virus that requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) to convert its RNA into DNA for detection. RT-PCR is a sensitive method used to detect and quantify RNA viruses by first converting their RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using the enzyme reverse transcriptase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses are DNA viruses and do not require reverse transcription. They can be detected using standard PCR methods that amplify their DNA directly.

 

Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr Virus is a DNA virus and uses standard PCR for detection. Reverse transcription is not necessary for DNA viruses.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus is also a DNA virus and can be detected through standard DNA PCR. Reverse transcription is not needed for its detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RSV, an RNA virus, requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) for detection by converting RNA into DNA.

questions.text: The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

The above picture is showing the structure of fungal cell wall most likely of Aspergillus fumigatus.

 

Fungal cell wall components - The fungal cell wall contains a cell membrane with various membrane proteins, a protective layer of chitin (yellow) as well as glucans (mostly beta) and mannoproteins on its surface. Different fungal cell walls contain different glucans. For example, the cell wall of A. fumigatus contains β-1,3- and β-1,4-glucan, and α-1,3-glucan, while C. albicans contains β-1,3- and β-1,6-glucan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis cell wall structure has three major cell wall features, including peptidoglycan, arabinogalactan and mycolic acid.

 

 

Option C. Mycoplasma pneumonia is bound by a trilaminar membrane that contains sterols. Cell wall is absent.

 

 

Option D. Recently, Rhinosporidium seeberi has been considered a fungus, but it was originally thought to be a protozoan parasite. Its morphologic characteristics resemble those of Coccidioides immitis: both organisms have mature stages that consist of large, thick-walled spherical structures containing smaller daughter cells (endospores). In addition, R. seeberi is visualized with fungal stains such as methenamine silver and periodic acid-Schiff, as well as mucicarmine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fungal cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus contains β-glucans, chitin, and mannoproteins.

questions.text: In a patient in the ICU, an infection in the central venous catheter is noted. Staining showed a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida

 

Candida is a genus of yeast and is the most common cause of fungal infections in humans. It is characterized by its oval shape and its mode of reproduction through budding, a form of asexual reproduction. In a healthcare setting, particularly in the ICU, Candida infections are commonly associated with the use of central venous catheters. The yeast can colonize and infect these catheters, leading to systemic infections. The identification of a gram-positive, oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding points directly to Candida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. E. coli: Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium and does not reproduce by budding. It is typically associated with gastrointestinal infections, urinary tract infections, and other bacterial infections, but not with the description provided in this scenario.

 

Option C. Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus in clusters and does not reproduce by budding. It is a common cause of various infections, including skin infections and catheter-associated infections, but its morphology and reproduction do not match the description of a budding organism.

 

Option D. Staph epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is also a gram-positive cocci and part of the normal skin flora. It is a common contaminant in blood cultures and can cause infections associated with indwelling medical devices, but it does not reproduce by budding and does not have an oval shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida is an oval-shaped yeast that reproduces by budding and is a common cause of catheter-associated infections in ICU patients.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Massive eosinophilia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea
  • It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis, etc
  • The classical features seen in lvmphatic filariasis are usually absent.
  • Elephantiasis - It refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brugia malayi and Option C. Brugia timori: Also cause lymphatic filariasis but have different morphological features in their microfilariae.

 

Option D. Mansonella perstans: Causes a different form of filariasis and has microfilariae that also have different characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are identified by their sheathed structure and the absence of nuclei at the tail end, crucial for the specific diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis caused by this parasite. This detail is significant for medical students and professionals working in endemic areas to recognize and diagnose the infection accurately.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

A-3. Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living amoeba uses pseudopodia for locomotion.

 

B-2. Balantidium coli, is a ciliated protozoan (and the largest protozoan that infects humans)

 

C-1. Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, flagellated protozoan parasite.

 

D-4.Toxoplasma gondii is a member of the phylum Apicomplexa, a diverse group of intracellular parasites that share a unique form of gliding motility. Gliding is substrate dependent and occurs without apparent changes in cell shape and in the absence of traditional locomotory organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balamuthia mandrillaris: Uses pseudopodia for movement.
  • Balantidium coli: Uses cilia for locomotion.
  • Trichomonas vaginalis: Uses flagella for movement.
  • Toxoplasma gondii: Exhibits gliding motility, a substrate-dependent movement without the use of traditional locomotory organelles.

choices.text: Denotes latent CMV infection
Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes
Indicates acute CMV infection
IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anti-CMV IgG antibodies? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

 

IgG avidity assays measure the binding strength between IgG antibodies and virus that can help distinguish a primary CMV infection from a past infection. Following primary CMV infection, IgG antibodies have low binding strength (low avidity) then over 2-4 months mature to high binding strength (high avidity). 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Denotes latent CMV infection: While the presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicates a past infection and potential latent infection, it does not specifically denote the current state of latency.

 

Option B. Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes: Anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicate past exposure and potential latent infection but do not confer immunity to all serotypes of CMV.

 

Option C. Indicates acute CMV infection: The presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies alone does not indicate an acute infection; it suggests past exposure. Acute CMV infection is usually indicated by the presence of anti-CMV IgM antibodies or a significant rise in IgG levels over time.

 

Educational objective

 

An IgG avidity assay is a useful tool to differentiate between a primary CMV infection and a past infection. Low avidity IgG indicates a recent infection, whereas high avidity IgG indicates a past infection.

questions.text: All of the following methods of cold sterilization except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Autoclave

 

Cold sterilization refers to sterilization methods that do not involve heat application. Autoclave operates at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, making it a hot sterilization method rather than a cold sterilization technique.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Plasma sterilization: 

 

  • This is a valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses gases in plasma state without temperature increase
  • Effective for heat-sensitive materials

 

Option B. Gamma rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses ionizing radiation
  • Does not increase temperature
  • Commonly used for medical devices and supplies

 

Option C. UV rays: 

 

  • Valid cold sterilization method
  • Uses non-ionizing radiation
  • Does not generate heat
  • Effective for surface sterilization

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Autoclave is a hot sterilization method operating at 121°C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI pressure, while plasma sterilization, gamma rays, and UV rays are cold sterilization methods that do not involve heat application.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The clinic history along with microscopic image is suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Gram-negative, intracellular, cocci, usually seen in pairs (diplococci) with the adjacent sides flattened (typically kidney-shaped); (Looks like two coffee beans kissing).

 

In urethral discharge, it is predominately found within the polymorphs.

 

Gonococci do not contain capsules (meningococci do).

 

Virulence factors -

 

  • Pili: Pili mediate attachment to mucosal cell surfaces and also are antiphagocytic. Piliated gonococci are usually virulent, whereas nonpiliated strains are avirulent.
  • Lipooligosaccharides (LOS)
  • Outer membrane proteins and Opa proteins eg. Porin A: mediates invasion of the epithelial cells.
  • IgA protease hydrolyzes secretory IgA, which could otherwise block the attachment of Neisseria gonorrheae to the mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan and not a gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes urethritis but is an obligate intracellular bacterium that does not show the gram-negative diplococcus morphology.

 

Option D. Gardnerella: Associated with bacterial vaginosis and presents as gram-variable coccobacilli, not gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of gram-negative, intracellular, kidney-shaped diplococci in urethral discharge is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhea, a common causative agent of sexually transmitted infections resulting in urethritis.

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. It is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, commonly known as "rose gardener's disease." This fungal infection occurs when the fungus, which lives in soil, plants, and decaying vegetation, enters the skin through small cuts or punctures. The infection usually starts as a small nodule at the site of entry and can spread along lymphatic channels, causing nodular lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans: This fungus is typically associated with systemic infections, particularly cryptococcal meningitis, in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS. It is not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: This is a systemic mycotic agent that causes histoplasmosis, a respiratory infection that can disseminate in immunocompromised individuals. It is not a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option D. Talaromyces marneffei: Formerly known as Penicillium marneffei, this fungus causes systemic mycoses, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS. It is endemic in Southeast Asia and not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The term systemic mycoses is used here to refer to infections caused by organisms in the following genera: Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Histoplasma, and Cryptococcus.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Somatic hypermutation

 

Affinity maturation is a process that occurs in B cells during an immune response, leading to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for their antigen. This process is primarily driven by somatic hypermutation (SHM).

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM): This involves the introduction of point mutations at a high rate in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin (Ig) genes in activated B cells. These mutations occur in the DNA encoding the variable regions of both heavy and light chains of the antibody molecule.
  • Selection for High Affinity: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively expanded. Those with mutations that increase the affinity of the antibody for its antigen are positively selected and proliferate, whereas B cells with lower affinity or non-functional antibodies are eliminated.
  • Result: This process leads to the production of high-affinity antibodies over time, enhancing the effectiveness of the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isotype Switching: Also known as class switch recombination, this process changes the antibody isotype (e.g., from IgM to IgG) but does not directly affect the antigen-binding affinity.

 

Option C. mRNA Splicing: This process involves the removal of introns from pre-mRNA to produce mature mRNA, but it is not involved in affinity maturation.

 

Option D. VDJ Rearrangement: This process generates the initial diversity of the antigen receptor repertoire by recombining variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments. It occurs before exposure to antigen and does not contribute to the increased affinity seen in affinity maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Affinity maturation, which results in the production of high-affinity antibodies, is primarily due to somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled with selective survival and proliferation of B cells producing high-affinity antibodies.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptospira

 

The life cycle shown in the images is indicative of leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira. The diagram highlights the transmission cycle involving various animal reservoirs and the environment, which is characteristic of leptospirosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanta virus: Transmitted through aerosolized rodent excreta but does not fit the detailed transmission cycle depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis: Causes plague, transmitted primarily through fleas, and does not follow the environmental cycle shown in the image.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food and water, and does not have a life cycle involving animal reservoirs as depicted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Leptospira involves transmission from animal reservoirs through contaminated water and soil, leading to human infection, which fits the depiction in the provided images.

questions.text: A woman in her reproductive age presented with a foul-smelling discharge, burning sensation, and lower abdominal pain. She also experiences dysuria. Pap smear is shown below. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichomonas

 

The Ans.  is Trichomonas because the symptoms and the findings on the Pap smear point directly towards a Trichomonas infection. Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that commonly causes sexually transmitted infections characterized by a foul-smelling discharge, burning sensation, lower abdominal pain, and dysuria. The Pap smear often shows pear-shaped trophozoites with characteristic jerky movements, which are indicative of Trichomonas.

 

The key feature on the Pap smear that helps in identifying Trichomonas is the presence of these trophozoites. This, combined with the clinical symptoms described, strongly supports the diagnosis of Trichomoniasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV infections are typically not sexually transmitted in this context and are not associated with foul-smelling vaginal discharge or the appearance seen on the Pap smear.

 

Option B. HPV (Human Papillomavirus): HPV can cause changes in the cervical cells seen on a Pap smear, but it does not cause the specific symptoms of foul-smelling discharge and burning sensation. HPV is more often linked with cervical dysplasia and warts.

 

Option C. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV typically presents with painful vesicular lesions rather than a foul-smelling discharge and is not characterized by the pear-shaped trophozoites seen on the Pap smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by a foul-smelling discharge, burning sensation, and the presence of pear-shaped trophozoites on a Pap smear.

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except: (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Babesia

 

Babesia is not an intracellular parasite of hepatocytes. It is an intra-erythrocytic parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Toxoplasma gondii can infect hepatocytes as part of its lifecycle.

 

Option B. Plasmodium: The liver stage (hepatic schizogony) of Plasmodium involves hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Leishmania: Leishmania species infect macrophages, which can reside in the liver, leading to intracellular infection in hepatocytes indirectly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obligate intracellular parasites-

 

  • Trypanosoma cruzi
  • Leishmania spp.
  • Plasmodium spp.
  • Babesia spp. -> RBC
  • Toxoplasma gondii
  • Microsporidia

choices.text: Nipah virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthrax

 

Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those deemed highest risk for use in bioterrorism due to their ease of dissemination or transmission and their high potential for significant public health impact, resulting in high mortality rates and the potential for major public health impact.

 

  • Characteristics of Anthrax:
    • Transmission: Can occur through cutaneous, inhalational, or gastrointestinal exposure to spore-forming bacteria.
    • Impact: Especially deadly in its inhalational form, anthrax can cause severe respiratory issues, shock, and often death if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah virus: It is not classified as a category A agent. It is a zoonotic virus that can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, primarily in Southeast Asia.

 

Option C. Coxiella: The bacterium that causes Q fever, is not classified as a category A agent. Q fever is typically acquired from infected animals or their products.

 

Option D. Brucella: It causes brucellosis, zoonotic infection primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Other category A agents are:

 

  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (Variola virus)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) - Francisella tularensis bacteria cause tularemia, also known as rabbit fever.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given staining technique? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia asteroids

 

The organism shown above is the Nocardia species. The above image shows acid-fast staining, where the organisms are shown appear as acid-fast (stained with fuschia) and branching rods or filaments. They are aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections in the immunocompromised.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, B: Mycobacteria species are acid-fast but do not have branching filaments.

 

Option C: Actinomyces species is gram-positive but not acid-fast.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are partially acid-fast, branching, filamentous rods that are found in the soil and cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of passive immunity? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoid

 

Passive immunity occurs when antibodies are transferred to an individual without stimulating their immune system. The key characteristic of passive immunity is that it provides immediate but temporary protection, as it doesn't involve the host's immune system actively producing antibodies. Passive immunity can be acquired naturally (through maternal transfer) or artificially (through immunoglobulin administration).

 

A toxoid, being a modified form of bacterial toxin, actually stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies, making it a form of active immunity rather than passive immunity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Antitoxin: Incorrect because antitoxins are preformed antibodies against specific toxins. When administered, they provide immediate protection without stimulating the immune system, making them a true example of passive immunity.

 

Option C. IgA: Incorrect because maternal IgA transferred through breast milk is a classic example of naturally acquired passive immunity, providing immediate protection to infants.

 

Option D. Monoclonal antibodies: Incorrect because these are laboratory-produced antibodies that provide immediate protection without stimulating the immune system, representing artificial passive immunity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Passive immunity involves direct antibody transfer without immune system stimulation, while active immunity (like toxoids) involves stimulating the immune system to produce its own antibodies.

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitides

 

  • The displayed picture illustrates a cell wall of a gram negative bacteria
  • It shows presence of  lipooligosaccharides (LOS), which strongly indicates the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Unlike lipopolysaccharide (LPS), LOS lacks a lengthy 0-antigen side chain.
  • This unique characteristic makes it a significant virulence factor, observed in only a limited number of organisms, including N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, H. ducreyi, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium and does not have a cell wall structure similar to the one depicted.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS instead of LOS.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS rather than LOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is identified by the presence of lipooligosaccharides (LOS) in its cell wall, a distinguishing feature of this gram-negative bacterium.

questions.text: A farmer presents with history of blunt trauma to the chest. There is formation of pus from the wound. Microscopy showed mildly acid fast bacteria with branching. What is the most likely organism? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nocardia species

 

The diagnosis of Nocardia is suggested by:

 

  1. Clinical presentation - History of trauma in a farmer (occupational exposure)
  2. Microscopic features: 
    • Mildly acid-fast (1% acid-fast positive)
    • Branching filamentous bacteria
    • Gram-positive staining pattern
  3. Formation of pus indicating suppurative infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

 

  • While acid-fast positive, does not show branching morphology
  • Primarily causes pulmonary TB through inhalation, not through trauma
  • Strongly acid-fast, not mildly acid-fast

 

Option C. Listeria:

 

  • Not acid-fast
  • Appears as small gram-positive rods
  • Does not show branching morphology

 

Option D. Anthrax:

 

  • Not acid-fast
  • Appears as gram-positive rods with square ends
  • Does not show branching pattern
  • Though associated with occupational exposure, presents differently

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nocardia is characterized by being:

 

  1. Mildly acid-fast (1% acid-fast positive)
  2. Shows branching filamentous morphology
  3. Common in traumatic injuries with soil contamination
  4. Important occupational pathogen

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parainfluenza

 

Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

 

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

 

Management:

 

  • ﻿﻿Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction.
  • Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • ﻿﻿Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>|V>|M). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • ﻿﻿Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (Sp02 <92 %)

 

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moraxella: More commonly associated with conditions like otitis media and sinusitis rather than croup.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Although capable of causing respiratory tract infections, it is not a typical cause of croup.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Known for more severe respiratory conditions like bacterial tracheitis, which is distinct from viral croup and presents with more severe symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parainfluenza is a common cause of croup. The 'Steeple sign' on X-ray supports this diagnosis, emphasizing the need for prompt and effective treatment to ensure rapid recovery and prevent complications.

questions.text: Desert rheumatism is caused by: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coccidioides immitis


Desert rheumatism, also known as Valley fever or California fever, is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis. This fungus is commonly found in desert regions, such as the southwestern United States, including California and Arizona. The disease is contracted by inhaling airborne fungal spores, which can cause symptoms ranging from mild flu-like conditions to severe pulmonary or disseminated infections. The mnemonic "Desert, Valley, Cali" helps remember the association with desert rheumatism, Valley fever, and California fever, all linked to Coccidioides immitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: This condition is caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, which is commonly found in bird and bat droppings, particularly in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. It does not cause desert rheumatism.

 

Option C. Mucormycosis: This is an infection caused by molds from the Mucorales order, which typically affects immunocompromised individuals. It is not associated with desert rheumatism.

 

Option D. Paracoccidioidomycosis: This disease is caused by the fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and occurs predominantly in South America. It is unrelated to desert rheumatism.

 

Educational Objective:


Desert rheumatism (Valley fever or California fever) is caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis.

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: The organism with following life cycle is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The given life cycle is of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Infective form - Filariform larvae

 

Natural host – Man

 

Mode of infection – penetration of skin by filariform larvae and autoinfection


 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that infects humans through skin penetration by its larvae.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides is a roundworm that infects humans through ingestion of contaminated food or water.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis is a pinworm that infects humans through ingestion of its eggs.

 

Educational Objective:
