The life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis involves skin penetration by filariform larvae and autoinfection.

choices.text: Sporothrix schenckii
Staphylococcus aureus
Nocardia asteroides

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Although Staphylococcus aureus can cause various skin infections, including cellulitis, abscesses, and impetigo, it does not typically spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics in the characteristic pattern of lymphocutaneous spread. Staphylococcus aureus usually causes localized infections.

 

Other Options

 

Organisms that can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," which presents with nodular lymphangitis, characterized by lesions following the lymphatic drainage.

 

Option C. Nocardia asteroides: Nocardiosis can present with cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions that spread along lymphatics, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes swimming pool granuloma or fish tank granuloma, presenting with skin lesions that spread along lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective

 

While Sporothrix schenckii, Nocardia asteroides, and Mycobacterium marinum are known to spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, causing lymphocutaneous lesions, Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized skin infections and does not exhibit this pattern of spread.

questions.text: A patient's plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Virus

 

Interferon-beta (IFN-β) is a type I interferon, which is predominantly secreted in response to viral infections. Interferons are proteins that play a crucial role in the immune response to pathogens, particularly viruses. They help inhibit viral replication within host cells and activate immune cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria: Bacterial infections are primarily associated with pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1, TNF-α, and IL-6, rather than type I interferons.

 

Option C. Fungi: Fungal infections do not typically induce high levels of interferon-beta.

 

Option D. Mycoplasm: Mycoplasma infections are more likely to induce other immune responses rather than a significant increase in interferon-beta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of interferons:

questions.text: Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sclerotic body

 

The histopathological picture shows brown coloured thick walled round cells that have transverse septations within them. These are called as Sclerotic bodies, also known as muriform cells or Medlar bodies, or copper penny appearance a found in tissue biopsies of patients with chromoblastomycosis. These bodies are a key diagnostic feature of this fungal infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Budding yeast: This is a general term for yeast cells reproducing through budding. It is not pathognomonic for a specific disease without further context.

 

Option C. Negri bodies are intracytoplasmic, round purplish structures with basophilic inner granules. They are pathognomic of rabies.

 

 

Option D. Asteroid bodies are oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. They are antigen-antibody complexes deposits. Seen in sporotricosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Few Important Pathognomonic structures associated with disease:

questions.text: The following image depicts: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Production of monoclonal antibodies

 

The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.

 

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

 

 

The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.

 

Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell lines for viral culture: This option is incorrect as the process depicted is not related to culturing cells for viral growth, but rather for antibody production.

 

Option C. Vaccine synthesis: This option is incorrect because vaccine synthesis generally involves the creation of attenuated or inactivated pathogens or their components, not the production of monoclonal antibodies.

 

Option D. Process of genetic engineering: This option is incorrect as genetic engineering involves manipulating an organism's genes directly, whereas the process depicted is about producing antibodies through hybridoma technology.

 

Educational Objective:


The process depicted in the images is the production of monoclonal antibodies using hybridoma technology.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD with a swollen, red knee joint that is tender to touch. 2 weeks prior, he had an episode of fever with bloody diarrhea. Which of the following could be the possible organism? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shigella

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of reactive arthritis after shigella infection.

 

Shigellosis is a diarrheal infection caused by Shigella species—gram-negative, non-spore forming, facultative anaerobes that infect the intestinal lining—and spread by fecal-oral transmission.

 

Shigella species (eg, S dysenteriae, S flexneri, S sonnei, S boydii) are aerobic, nonmotile, glucose-fermenting, gram-negative rods that are highly contagious, causing diarrhea after ingestion of as few as 180 organisms.

 

These pathogens cause damage by two mechanisms, (1) invasion of the colonic epithelium, which is dependent on a plasmid-mediated virulence factor, and (2) production of an enterotoxin, which is not essential for colitis but enhances the virulence.

 

Symptoms of shigellosis include acute bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping, tenesmus, urgency, fever, occasional vomiting and dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli: Certain strains of E. coli (such as EHEC) can cause bloody diarrhea and may lead to complications like Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), but reactive arthritis is less commonly associated with E. coli.

 

Option C. Giardia: Giardia typically causes watery diarrhea rather than bloody diarrhea and is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

 

Option D. Rotavirus: Rotavirus infection primarily causes watery diarrhea in young children and is not associated with bloody diarrhea or reactive arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reactive arthritis can occur following an infection with Shigella species, which is known for causing bloody diarrhea. This condition presents with joint inflammation and pain, typically occurring several weeks after the initial gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Infection with Shigella species may be associated with extra gastrointestinal complications-

 

  1. Bacteremia
  2. Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome characterized by acute hemolysis, renal failure, uremia, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  3. Metabolic disturbances: Hyponatremia secondary to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion may occur.
  4. Leukemoid reaction: An elevated white blood cell (WBC) count of 50,000/mm3 occurs in approximately 4% of patients, mainly in children aged 2-10 years.
  5. Neurologic disease: Seizures, the most common neurologic complication.
  6. Encephalopathy with lethargy, confusion, and headache
  7. Reactive arthritis (also known as Reiter syndrome) may occur.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin
Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts, suggestive of modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid fast (holding capacity).

 

Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence, they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure.

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain).

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly. Heat is used as mordant (A mordant is a substance that increases the affinity of the cell wall for a stain by binding to the primary stain, thus forming an insoluble complex, which gets trapped in the cell wall). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is not used for modified acid-fast staining but is related to Gram staining.

 

Option C. Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet: This is incorrect as the proper primary stain for the modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain is Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin.

 

Option D. Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is incorrect for modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain uses methanol for fixation, Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, acid alcohol for decolorization, and methylene blue as the counterstain to detect acid-fast organisms like Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are typically made from the polysaccharide capsule that surrounds certain bacteria. These vaccines are designed to protect against bacterial infections by inducing immunity against the polysaccharide antigens present in the capsule.

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant vaccine that uses a portion of the hepatitis B virus (HBsAg - hepatitis B surface antigen) produced in yeast cells. This vaccine does not involve a polysaccharide component as the hepatitis B virus does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal: The pneumococcal vaccine is available in both polysaccharide (PPSV23) and conjugate forms (PCV13), targeting the polysaccharide capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Meningococcal: Meningococcal vaccines also include polysaccharide (MPSV4) and conjugate forms (MCV4), aimed at the polysaccharide capsule of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option C. H. influenzae: The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a conjugate vaccine that includes the polysaccharide antigen from the bacterial capsule conjugated to a protein carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

choices.text: The organism does not invade underlying fascia, tendon, muscle, or joints.
Angioinvasion is common, especially in people with hemolytic anemia.
It is a dimorphic organism, and yeast forms are seen in clinical sample.
These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages.

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The organism does not invade underlying fascia, tendon, muscle, or joints.

 

Clinical history along with sclerotic bodies on histopathology is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis and it does not commonly invade underlying tissue, tendon, or joints.

 

Chromoblastomycosis (CBM) is defined as a chronic cutaneous and subcutaneous fungal infection resulting from traumatic implantation of certain dematiaceous fungi through the skin.

 

In a typical manifestation the dermal lesions form cauliflower-like nodules. In the infected tissue, characteristic dark-colored, thick-walled, muriform cells i.e., sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) are observed, which is a histopathological criterion for the diagnosis.

 

The most frequent aetiological agents of CBM are the following species: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa and Cladophialophora carrionii.

 

The etiological agent (i.e., fungal fragment) gains entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. Cases of buttock, trunk and face infection have also been reported. In more advanced stages of the disease dissemination may occur in the form of satellite lesions which arise from scratching autoinoculation and spread via the lymphatic system.

 

Treatment – Antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine. Surgical excision is the therapy of choice for small lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angioinvasion is common, especially in people with hemolytic anemia: Angioinvasion is not a common feature of chromoblastomycosis. It is more characteristic of invasive fungal infections like aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

 

Option C. It is a dimorphic organism, and yeast forms are seen in clinical samples: Chromoblastomycosis is caused by fungi that are not typically dimorphic. They exist in the form of sclerotic bodies in clinical samples, rather than yeast forms. Dimorphic fungi, such as Histoplasma capsulatum and Blastomyces dermatitidis, exhibit different morphologies at different temperatures (mold at 25°C and yeast at 37°C).

 

Option D. These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages: Sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) are not formed by macrophages engulfing dead fungi. They are thick-walled fungal cells characteristic of chromoblastomycosis, representing the fungal morphology in the infected tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by skin lesions containing sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) and does not typically invade deeper tissues such as fascia, tendons, muscles, or joints.

questions.text: A patient presents with a mobile, warm to touch nodule in the neck. On the anaerobic culture of the biopsy material from this swelling, it showed colonies as shown in the image which had gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth suggestive of actinomycete infection of cervicofacial region also called as Lumpy jaw.

 

Culture characteristics - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth.

 

Gram-positive filamentous branching rods. Non-motile, non-sporing and non-acid-fast. Clumps of the organisms can be seen as yellowish ‘sulphur granules’ in pus discharging from sinus tracts, or the granules can be squeezed out of the lesions.

 

Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin such as amoxicillin are now popular. Clindamycin and erythromycin are effective in patients with penicillin allergy. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Effective for certain infections but not the first-line treatment for actinomycete infections.

 

Option B. Cotrimoxazole: Not typically used for actinomycete infections.

 

Option D. Surgical drainage: May be required as an adjunct to antibiotic therapy in chronic cases, but it is not the primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penicillin is the drug of choice for treating actinomycete infections, particularly in cervicofacial cases presenting with nodules and characteristic colonies. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is necessary, and surgical intervention may be required for chronic lesions.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms. This condition arises from a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex in phagocytes, which is crucial for the production of reactive oxygen species used to kill ingested pathogens.

 

Key points about CGD:

 

  • Pathophysiology: In CGD, phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils and macrophages) are unable to produce reactive oxygen species due to a defective NADPH oxidase enzyme. This impairs the killing of certain bacteria and fungi.
  • Catalase-positive organisms: These organisms can neutralize hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a reactive oxygen species that the host cells might produce. Catalase-positive bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Aspergillus species, Nocardia, and Pseudomonas.
  • Recurrent Infections: Patients with CGD frequently suffer from recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms due to their inability to effectively kill these pathogens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyper IgM syndrome: This immunodeficiency disorder is characterized by elevated levels of IgM and low levels of other immunoglobulins due to defects in class-switch recombination. Patients are more prone to infections but not specifically with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Job syndrome (Hyper-IgE syndrome): Patients with Job syndrome have elevated levels of IgE and suffer from recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, pneumonia, and other infections. However, their susceptibility is not specifically related to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defects in lysosomal trafficking, leading to impaired phagocytosis and recurrent bacterial infections. While patients are prone to infections, their susceptibility is not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme in phagocytes.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, typically presenting with symptoms such as muscle weakness, paralysis, and respiratory failure rather than rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Associated with gastroenteritis that causes abdominal cramps and diarrhea, typically occurring 8-16 hours after consumption of contaminated food.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and other systemic symptoms, rather than immediate vomiting.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene

 

Resistance to ganciclovir (GCV) most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene.

 

Viral UL97 kinase and UL54 DNA polymerase gene mutations are well-documented mechanisms of resistance to current antivirals. The UL97 kinase normally phosphorylates serine and threonine residues of various cellular and viral proteins, and is required for efficient CMV replication. This kinase also effects the initial phosphorylation of GCV that is required for antiviral activity, and UL97 mutations that impair this phosphorylation are the preferred mechanism of GCV resistance.

 

UL54 mutations can confer resistance to all current drugs and may emerge after prolonged GCV therapy to increase the level of resistance conferred by a pre-existing UL97 mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the host.

 

Option C: CMV infection is mostly subclinical. In immunocompromised individuals, CMV can cause various manifestations, including retinitis, colitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis, but watery diarrhea is not the most common manifestation.

 

Option D: UL54 mutations can confer resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir, and foscamet. These mutations affect the viral DNA polymerase, leading to cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CMV is ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. This gene is responsible for the initial phosphorylation of ganciclovir, and mutations here can prevent the drug's activation, leading to resistance. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, and UL54 mutations can confer cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs, including foscarnet. CMV infections are mostly subclinical, and the common manifestations in immunocompromised patients are not typically watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn. The given image shows a positive oxidase test. Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

 

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

 

  • ﻿﻿Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • ﻿﻿Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • ﻿﻿Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • ﻿﻿Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • ﻿﻿Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • ﻿﻿Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: While also a common hospital-acquired pathogen, it is typically associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections, not specifically burns.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Commonly causes gastrointestinal and urinary infections but is not typically associated with burn infections.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Known for causing gastrointestinal infections, not burn wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

 

Oxidase positive organisms:

 

  • ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ﻿Burkholderia

questions.text: Choose the egg belonging to the following parasite from the column B? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

The above worm is Enterobius vermicularis

 

Adults are short, white, fusiform worms with pointed ends, looking like bits of white thread. The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like curricular expansions (cervical alae), which are transversely striated. as seen in the image provided in the question. The esophagus has a double bulb structure, a feature unique to this worm.

 

 

The egg is colorless and not bile-stained. It floats in saturated salt solution. It has a characteristic shape, being elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other (planoconvex), measuring 50-60 μm by 20-30 μm. The eggshell is double-layered and relatively thick, though transparent. The outer albuminous layer makes the eggs stick to each other and to clothing and other objects. The egg contains a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo, which is fully formed, but becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited on the skin. Under cool moist conditions, the egg remains viable for about 2 weeks.

 

 

The correctly matched egg for the given parasite - Enterobius vermicularis is 3

 

Other choices:
 

Option A: Egg of Hymenolepsis nana
 

Option B: Egg of Tenia species 
 

Option D: Fertilized egg of ascaris
 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis eggs are elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other, with a double-layered, thick, transparent shell and contain a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo.

questions.text: Parthenogenesis is seen in which of the following worm?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction where the female organism is capable of producing offspring without the need for fertilization by a male. In the case of parasitic worms, this phenomenon is specifically seen in Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Reference Paragraph Explanation:

 

  1. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the nematodes because it can reproduce through parthenogenesis. This means that the female worms can produce fertile eggs without mating with a male. In the human host, only female Strongyloides worms are found in the intestine, and they are capable of producing eggs or larvae without male fertilization.
  2. Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes:
    • Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris.
    • Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria.
    • Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichuris trichura: This worm is oviparous, meaning it lays eggs that develop and hatch outside the female’s body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is also an oviparous worm. It lays eggs that develop in the external environment.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, it is also oviparous, laying eggs that hatch outside the body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parthenogenesis, where a female worm can produce offspring without male fertilization, is a unique reproductive strategy seen in Strongyloides stercoralis. This worm is also oviviparous, laying eggs that hatch almost immediately.

questions.text: Which type of PCR is suitable for identifying multiple causative agents? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiplex PCR    

 

Multiplex PCR is a technique that allows the simultaneous amplification of multiple target sequences in a single PCR reaction. This makes it particularly useful for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, such as when diagnosing conditions like diarrhea that can be caused by a variety of pathogens including viruses, bacteria, and fungi. Multiplex PCR uses multiple sets of primers in a single reaction mixture, each specific for a different target, allowing the detection of multiple organisms in one run.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conventional PCR: This method involves amplifying a single DNA target per reaction and is not designed to handle multiple targets simultaneously, making it less suitable for identifying multiple causative agents.

 

Option B. Real-time PCR: While real-time PCR can quantify DNA or RNA targets and is highly sensitive, it typically amplifies one target per reaction or a few targets in separate reactions rather than multiple agents in a single test.

 

Option D. Nested PCR: This technique is designed to increase the specificity of PCR by using two sets of primers in two successive runs, but it is not intended for simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens. It is primarily used to reduce non-specific binding and enhance detection sensitivity for a specific target.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiplex PCR is the best choice for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, making it efficient and comprehensive for diagnosing conditions caused by various pathogens.

choices.text: Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: Cholangiocarcinoma is not a complication of?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that forms in the bile ducts. It is associated with various risk factors and conditions, but Hepatitis B is not directly linked to its development. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is primarily associated with hepatocellular carcinoma, which is a different type of liver cancer. The other options listed are known risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Opisthorchis: This parasitic infection is a known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. 

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This chronic liver disease involving inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts is a significant risk factor for developing cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Caroli's disease: This congenital disorder characterized by cystic dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts increases the risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus primarily causes hepatocellular carcinoma, not cholangiocarcinoma, unlike other liver conditions such as parasitic infections, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and Caroli's disease.

questions.text: Match the following parasites with their respective hosts: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

  • Diphyllobothrium latum: Humans (definitive host), Cyclops (first intermediate host), and Fish (second intermediate host).
  • Paragonimus westermani: Humans (definitive host), Snail (first intermediate host), Crayfish and Crab (second intermediate host).
  • Brugia malayi: Humans (definitive host), Mansonia mosquito (intermediate host).
  • Fasciola hepatica: Sheep and Humans (definitive hosts), Snail (first intermediate host), Aquatic vegetation (second intermediate host).

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of: (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans.

 

Germ tube test is a screening test for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. Candida dubliniensis can also form germ tubes and Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that closely resemble germ tubes.

 

Germ tube formation was first reported by Reynolds and Braude and hence the germ tube test is also known as Reynolds-Braude phenomenon.

 

Buds and pseudo-hyphae can be distinguished from germ tubes by the constricted attachment at the point of origin. Germ tubes don’t show constriction at the point of origin.

 

Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis produce short, slender, tube-like structures called germ tubes.

 

The formation of germ tubes is associated with increased synthesis of protein and ribonucleic acid. Various media like fetal bovine serum may be used as a substitute for human pooled serum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida glabrata: Candida glabrata does not produce germ tubes. It forms small, round yeast cells.

 

Option C. Candida parapsilosis: Candida parapsilosis does not produce germ tubes. It forms pseudohyphae and yeast cells.

 

Option D. Candida tropicalis: Candida tropicalis can produce pseudohyphae that resemble germ tubes, but they show constriction at the point of origin. This is a distinguishing feature from the true germ tubes of Candida albicans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The germ tube test is used for the presumptive identification of Candida albicans. It detects the formation of germ tubes, which are characteristic of Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis but not other Candida species. Germ tubes are short, slender, tube-like structures without constriction at their point of origin, differentiating them from pseudohyphae.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

 

The symptoms with the microscopic findings which shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci suggests infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

 

Treatment of Gonorrhoea –

 

  • Third generation cephalosporins – DOC for uncomplicated gonococcal infection - both the sexual partners should be treated.
  • Ceftriaxone (250 mg given IM, single dose)
  • Cefixime (400 mg given orally, single dose)
  • If coexisting chlamydial infection – azithromycin or doxycycline added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythromycin and Option B. Azithromycin are macrolides, generally used for chlamydial infections or as a co-treatment when chlamydia is suspected alongside gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Penicillin G is no longer recommended as the primary treatment for gonorrhea due to widespread resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucormycosis

 

The β 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis.

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (Mucor, Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect BDG (in ng/ml) by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes.

 

Level of ≥80 pg/mL is considered a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: The β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose candidiasis as Candida species produce BDG.

 

Option B. Aspergillosis: The assay is also effective for diagnosing aspergillosis since Aspergillus species produce BDG.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis pneumonia: Pneumocystis jirovecii, the causative agent of Pneumocystis pneumonia, produces BDG, making the assay useful for its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The β 1-3 glucan assay is not effective for diagnosing mucormycosis because the fungi causing mucormycosis (Mucor, Rhizopus) either lack (1-3)-β-D-glucan or produce it at minimal levels. This assay is useful for diagnosing fungal infections like candidiasis, aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis pneumonia which involve fungi that produce significant levels of BDG.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with history of fever and enlarged lymph nodes and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mono-nucleosis and was ordered a Paul Bunnel test. Which of the following is the principle of the test? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibody test

 

  • Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody reaction test and is used in glandular fever like Infectious mononucleosis.
  • Heterophile antibodies have the ability to agglutinate RBCs of different animal species.
  • Paul Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes for agglutination and Monospot test uses horse erythrocytes for agglutination.
  • In Infectious Mononucleosis, IgM heterophile antibodies are detectable for the first 3 months of infection and they can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Complement mediated cell damage: This refers to a different mechanism where the complement system causes lysis of cells. It is not related to the principle of the Paul Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Precipitation reaction uses a soluble antigen to form a precipitate in a solid media when combined with an antibody.

 

Option D. Neutralisation reaction: Neutralization reactions involve antibodies that neutralize the pathogen, preventing it from infecting cells. This principle does not apply to the Paul Bunnell test.

 

Educational Objective

 

The Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody test used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis. It detects IgM heterophile antibodies that can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, which are present during the early stages of the infection.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

 

The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy.

 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallium. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

 

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

 

  • Treponemes generally are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electron microscope: While capable of revealing detailed structures of microorganisms, it is not typically used in clinical settings for diagnosing infections due to its complexity and cost.

 

Option C. Light microscope: Standard light microscopy, typically used with staining techniques, does not easily allow for the visualization of live motility or very thin bacteria like Treponema pallidum.

 

Option D. Fluorescent microscope: Although it can be used to detect specific pathogens if fluorescent-tagged antibodies are available, it is not the standard method for observing motility or diagnosing syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is essential for observing the motility of Treponema pallidum directly from lesions such as a syphilitic chancre. This diagnostic tool is critical in early stages of syphilis when direct visualization of the pathogen can confirm infection before serological tests become positive.

questions.text: What does ‘H’ indicate in a patient presenting with a history of EHEC O157:H7? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flagella

 

In the nomenclature of bacteria, specifically Escherichia coli (E. coli) strains like EHEC O157, the ‘H’ antigen refers to the flagellar antigen. Flagella are whip-like structures that allow bacteria to be motile. The ‘O’ antigen represents the somatic (cell wall) antigen, which is associated with the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) layer of the bacterial cell wall. Therefore, the ‘H’ antigen is specifically linked to flagella, which is crucial for bacterial motility and plays a role in pathogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Capsule: The capsule is a polysaccharide layer that surrounds some bacterial cells, providing protection against the host immune system. It is not related to the ‘H’ antigen.

 

Option B. Fimbriae: Fimbriae are short, hair-like structures on the bacterial surface that assist in adherence to surfaces and are not related to the ‘H’ antigen. They are different from flagella and do not contribute to motility.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharide: Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is part of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria and is associated with the ‘O’ antigen, not the ‘H’ antigen. It plays a significant role in the immune response but is unrelated to bacterial motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In bacterial antigen classification, the ‘H’ antigen corresponds to flagella, which are essential for motility.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with watery diarrhea and vomiting. Electron microscopy showed the following image. Identify the organism: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotavirus

 

The clinical presentation of watery diarrhea and vomiting in a 2-year-old child, combined with the electron microscopy image showing wheel-like structures, strongly indicates Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is easily identified by its characteristic wheel-like appearance under electron microscopy. The virus is known for causing gastroenteritis in infants and young children, leading to dehydration if not managed properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenovirus: While adenoviruses can cause gastroenteritis, they do not have the characteristic wheel-like appearance seen in electron microscopy. Adenovirus typically presents with a different capsid morphology that lacks the wheel-like structure of Rotavirus.

 

Option C. Norwalk virus: Also known as Norovirus, this virus is a common cause of gastroenteritis but has a distinct cup-like morphology on electron microscopy, not the wheel-like appearance seen with Rotavirus.

 

Option D. Astrovirus: Astrovirus can cause diarrhea in young children, but it has a star-like appearance under electron microscopy, differing from the wheel-like appearance of Rotavirus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is characterized by its distinctive wheel-like appearance on electron microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique is '2'.

 

 

The sandwich ELISA is a type of Enzyme-linked immunosorbent Assay that uses two antibodies: a capture antibody and a detection antibody. It is called a sandwich because your antigen is bound between antibodies. The purpose of any ELISA is to detect the presence of a target antigen in a sample. In a sandwich ELISA the target antigen is bound between a capture antibody and a detection antibody. The capture antibody is immobilized on a surface, while the detection antibody (conjugated to an enzyme or fluorophore label) is applied as a last step before quantitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Represents the substrate that produces a detectable signal when reacted with the enzyme.

 

Option C. 3: Represents the primary detection antibody that binds to the antigen.

 

Option D. 4: Represents the capture antibody that is immobilized on the surface and captures the antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the sandwich ELISA technique, the enzyme conjugate is part of the detection antibody, which binds to the antigen and, upon addition of a substrate, produces a detectable signal. In this diagram, '2' is identified as the enzyme conjugate.
